awd_titl_txt: Competition Between Contractility and Surface Tension in Collective Cell Migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological cells migrate in groups both during healthy life and also during diseases during tissue changes ranging from wound repair to cancer progression. The migration can restore normal function of damaged tissue, as in wound repair, or further the spread of disease, as in a spreading cancer. In both wound healing and cancer, it is typical for cells to migrate together where each cell's motion depends its own active contractile forces and its interaction with neighbors. The resulting cellular motions can vary dramatically--from a solid-like state, where each cell remains close to its neighbors, to a fluid-like state, where each cell freely migrates past its neighbors. The transition between solid-like and fluid-like migration occurs in both wound healing and cancer invasion and its causes remain unclear. Theoretical models have predicted that the transition depends on the adhesion molecules between neighboring cells, and, counterintuitively, that greater adhesion causes a more fluid-like behavior.  This prediction is complicated by the fact that some molecules associated with cell-cell adhesion also cause cells to contract and pull against their neighbors. The work will experimentally examine the competing roles of adhesion and contraction on collective migration, thereby clarifying our understanding of collective migration and providing new insights into how the migration may be promoted in wound healing or reduced during cancer progression.  The PI will recruit undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering through the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) program in the College of Engineering at UW-Madison. Through the SURE program, these students will gain research experience and will be encouraged to pursue graduate studies.

This research will test the hypothesis that the solid-to-fluid transition results from a balance between the active contractile tension inside each cell and the adhesive surface energy at each cell-cell interface. To quantify intercellular adhesion, this project will use a mechanically rigorous definition, the surface tension. To quantify contraction, it will use the contractile stress within each cell. Surface tension and contractile stress will be modulated by using pharmacological inhibitors and transfections of appropriate signaling pathways, and they will be measured by using state-of-the art optical microscopy and quantitative image analysis. The first objective of this research will reveal how the intracellular surface tension results from the balance between the actomyosin contraction in each cell's cortex and the adherens junctions at each cell-cell interface. The second objective will investigate how contractility and surface tension together regulate the multicellular motion. The resulting data will give a complete account of the mechanics of collective cellular motion, and thus they will provide an empirical basis for testing theories for the mechanisms of collective migration.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This research studied collective motion of biological cells, which is a topic that is important in numerous processes in human health and disease ranging from wound repair to cancer progression. The migration may either restore the normal function of damaged tissue, as in wound repair, or further the spread of disease, as in cancer progression. The objective of the research was to focus on a recently discovered phenomenon, that the cell migration can transition between a solid-like state, wherein each cell remains caged in place by its neighbors, to a fluid-like state, wherein each cell freely migrates past its neighbors. The transition between solid-like and fluid-like is thought to occur in both wound healing and cancer invasion, but its cause has been unclear. The research studied two physical factors thought to affect the transition, the contractile forces produced within the cell, and the adhesion forces at the cell periphery. The experiments were designed to test a prior theoretical model predicting that fluid-like motion was associated with elongated cells, having a large perimeter compared to area. In agreement with this prediction, the results showed fluid-like motion associated with elongated cells with larger perimeter, but the underlying cause of cell elongation was surprising. Instead of cell elongation being associated with the forces of adhesion at the cell periphery as previously thought, it was caused by forces transmitted from each cell to the substrate beneath it. This finding changed understanding in the field, and focused attention on the forces at the cell-substrate interface. To follow up on this finding, additional experiments were designed to determine the effect of intracellular forces and cell-substrate forces on the collective migration. One set of experiments revealed that cells coordinate with their neighbors to apply cell-substrate forces in the same direction. This finding opens up the exciting possibility that future research could use the coordination between neighbors to control the collective migration, which would, for example, offer a means to accelerate wound healing.

 

Experimental data and computational software used in this research have been uploaded to freely available online repositories and are described in detail in the publications supported by this award.

 

Broader impacts of this research were in training of graduate and undergraduate students. Specifically, one graduate student and three undergraduate students participated in the research, in which they developed important skills in critical thinking, teamwork, communication, and problem solving. Methods used in the research were also implemented as a module in a course on Quantitative Methods in Biology, which has been completed by numerous graduate students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2021
Modified by: Jacob K Notbohm
